description.narrative:
Den fjärde fasen av Diakonias demokratiprogram i Somalia täckte ursprungligen perioden 1 april 2011 - 31 mars 2014. Enligt det ursprungliga beslutet utgick ett Sidastöd på SEK 40 400 000. Genom ett tilläggsbeslut i april 2013 avsattes ytterligare SEK 4 040 000.
Den 12 februari 2014 inkom Diakonia med ett önskemål om en förlängning av avtalsperioden med tre månader. Utan ytterligare bidrag. I ett brev daterat 11 mars 2014 godkänner Sida denna "no cost extension" och kommer via brevväxling överens om konsekvensändringar i avtalet.
Den 28 februari 2014 inkommer Diakonia med en ansökan gällande den kommande fasen av programmet. Programmet heter "The Somalia Rights Programme 2014-2018. Promoting human rights through civil society in Puntland and Jubaland" och täcker den 4,5-åriga perioden juli 2014 - december 2018.
Den 25 mars 2014 hålls ett möte mellan Diakonia och ambassaden/Sida. Vid detta möte meddelar Sida att ansökan gällande nästa fas bör utvecklas ytterligare. Bl a behöver förutsättningarna för det planerade arbetet i Jubaland studeras mer grundligt. Diakonia och Sida kommer vid mötet överens om att det lämpligaste är att fördröja nästa programfas med sex månader så att aktivitetsperioden inleds den 1 januari 2015. Diakonia kommer under övergångsperioden (1 juli - 31 december 2014) att vidareutveckla sina planer och senast den 15 oktober skicka in en reviderad ansökan. Ambassaden uppmuntrar Diakonia att kontraktera extra stöd för att få bästa möjliga förutsättningar för att göra en gedigen revision av ansökan. Vidare kommer parterna överens om att Diakonia ska ges möjlighet att under den kommande 6-månadersperioden upprätta och pröva en fond som ska kunna användas till mindre men snabba insatser i Somalia - i samråd med ambassaden. I övrigt kommer parterna överens om att Diakonias reguljära verksamhet och samarbete med sina somaliska partners ska kunna fortsätta under övergångsperioden.
Diakonia inkom den 11 april med en ansökan (inkl budget) gällande övergångsperioden 1 juli - 31 december 2014. Denna innehöll dock inte några medel för fonden, som givits namnet Rapid Response Mechanism. En ny komplett ansökan inkom till Ambassaden den 11 maj 2014. Det är denna ansökan som ligger till grund för det nu förestående beslutet.
Diakonias ansökan ligger helt i linje med de synpunkter som ambassaden kommunicerat till organisationen, inkl vid det ovan nämnda mötet den 25 mars. I korthet innehåller ansökan följande:
* Ett fortsatt samarbete med Diakonias partners i enlighet med demokratiprogrammets fjärde fas som inleddes i april 2011. * Tematiska studier samt "baseline studies" som ska ligga till grund för utformningen av programmet för den kommande fasen. * Utredning av förutsättningarna för upprättandet av ett Diakoniakontor i Jubaland. Om förutsättningar finns inleds arbetet med att avtala om samarbete med lokala partners och kontraktera lokal personal. * Översyn av Diakonias organisation. * Inrättandet av en fond (Rapid Response Mechanism) under en försöksperiod.
Den totala budgeten uppgår enligt ansökan till SEK 8 914 066.
Support to the Diakonia democracy programme in Puntland and South-Central Somalia, phase IV

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Diakonia's Democracy and Human Rights programme (Phase IV) which was dubbed ' An integrated approach to Enhance Democracy and Human Rights in Sool, Sanag, Puntland and Galmudug was implemented during the period 1 April 2011- 30 June 2015.
The programme had an overall objective of promoting democracy, human rights and gender equality in North-East and Central-South Somalia; with the specific objective of empowering the community through the civil society to qualitatively participate in the democratisation process in Sool, Sanaag, Puntland and Galmudug. In the external evaluation, dated January 2014, the results are described as follows: "The programme worked: it delivered significant successes and leaves a legacy of individuals and institutions that can continue to improve democracy and human rights in the region and beyond. The partners are appropriate and have an ongoing capacity to deliver further programmes. The high-quality staff has ensured that local ownership is high and that Diakonia has an excellent reputation. The programme did the right things, most often in the right way." Even if the evaluators may be overly positive and optimistic, the Embassy agrees that the programme has worked and produced important results albeit with some hiccups and delays.
Key highlights of the results achieved include the following:
The programme carried out 6 dialogue forums on taxation and government resource mobilization. These forums enlightened the community on the duty of citizens to pay taxes, the role taxes play and the importance of fostering transparency, accountability, public engagement and information sharing. This process was implemented in collaboration with Diakonia's Tax- Justice Network- Africa programme (TJN-A), which yielded in successful results , one of them being the development of a comprehensive tax framework, and the engagement of Puntland government and the International Humanitarian Organizations operating in Puntland to pledge to pay tax according to Puntland tax laws. A taxation policy framework was developed and implemented in Puntland. It defined the formula for calculation of tax, the process of tax collection and the responsibility of various actors. A Community Accountability Network (CAN) was formed by Civil Society to engage the government on taxation matters. The role of this network is to advocate for the payment of taxes as an obligation of every citizen in nation building and also follow-up on the expenditure patterns of the government in order to guide and pressure the government in issues concerning budgeting, taxation and spending. The programme recognizes that CAN in its present form is a stop gap measure and will need to be reviewed when full decentralization takes place.
The programme held 9 dialogues at community level to improve the relations between police and citizens with a view to enhance the rule of law in Puntland. The dialogue culminated in the formation of 4 Neighbourhood Security Committees (NCS) to assist in community policing alongside the police. The four committees were assisted in engaging the police at a higher level. In a meeting attended by 80 participants with high ranking police officials in attendance, the committees were legitimized and their role seen as crucial in enhancing the rule of law in Puntland. The NSC has assisted the police in enhancing the security in the community, by functioning as a facilitator in the communication between the citizens and the police, providing useful information and increasing the trust and understanding between them. In addition, their were fruitful interactions, as a result of which mistrust between the police and citizens has reduced and the collaboration between the two improved.
Also, a committee was established to address and raise awareness on the issue of land grabbing, which came about through public gatherings and announcements in the media. This intervention facilitated to clarify the complexity of land and property regulations, which made people realize the importance of legal and regulatory frameworks, and encouraged the people as well as civil society to engage and lobby for the government to formulate effective laws and policies and enforcing them. Peace clubs were formed at schools to tackle issues of bullying and conflicts among students and to promote a culture of peace, unity and comradeship at the schools.
The programme also created other platforms and dialogue forums to enable the government and civil society to directly interact, raise concerns, build trust and share information. By creating a conducive environment to promote good relations, accountability and responsiveness, this intervention strengthened the linkage and trust between the public and government, which also laid the foundation for improved understanding and good cooperation.
The scholarship programme for the girls provided an opportunity to girls who would have otherwise not received an education without the intervention of the programme. The tracer study of the girls that received scholarship provided information on what the impact of USD 8 per month invested in the life of a girl can achieve. Some of girls are now young women attending university, working or having other engagements. The scholarship programme for girls is a great way of providing gender equality in a fragile context where boys are favoured.
Through competence development and accompaniment provided by the programme, in collaboration with Fojo Media Institute, the Puntland media sector achieved several set of objectives including; the development of a new draft media law, platform provided for the government and media to discuss and strengthen their relationship, self- regulation of media has been formally accepted by the Government, and a Code of Conduct for Elections reporting was developed. These developments lay the foundation for a sound media environment to prosper.
The programme supported the translation and printing of a Somali version of the Do No Harm Booklet, which has been widely used by other actors in the assistance to conflict sensitive programming. The trainers trained in the programme have continued to provide guidance and assistance to other organizations in conflict sensitive programming.
